questions.question_text: Creating a hard link to an ordinary file returns an error. What could be the reason for this?

discussion.content: Creating a hard link to an ordinary file can fail if the source and the target are on different filesystems. This is because hard links can only be created within the same filesystem or partition. This is a limitation of the filesystem, and attempting to create a hard link across filesystems will result in an error.

choices.E: The source and the target are on different filesystems.
choices.C: The source file is a shell script.
choices.D: The source file is already a hard link.

discussion.content:
A. /sbin/mke2fs -j /dev/sdb1 creates an ext3 filesystem on /dev/sdb1. The -j option is used to create an ext3 filesystem, which is an upgraded version of the ext2 filesystem with journaling capabilities.

B. /sbin/mkfs -t ext3 /dev/sdb1 also creates an ext3 filesystem on /dev/sdb1. The -t option specifies the type of the filesystem, which in this case is ext3.
